page.title: 07EDUCATION
page.content: Two problems confront the provision of education in Lancaster. The first is that secondary education in the city is still based upon selection at age 11+. Despite repeated efforts since 1974 attempts to reorganise have failed. The governors of Lancaster Royal Grammar school wish to keep their status,and only an act of Parliament can change the character of their school. Conse- quently education in Lancaster in 1985 remains divisive and ill-coordinated. Apart from the separate boys and girls grammar schools there is a C.of E.aided school,a catholic school, and three secondary moderns.This lack of cohesion is most unsatisfactory and is a product of entrenched, vested interests. The failure to reorgainise on comprehensive lines is a recurring problem and no answer is right. Only different central government policy can solve it.
